comment.text: works with prop. nvidia driver from rpmfusion and VirtualBox 6.0.4 from Oracle on Intel i5-3550
Works for me. No regressions noted.
Works for me in VM. No regressions noted.

Works for me..  
The Default and Performance Regression tests pass OK. AMD 965, x86_64 work station, Plasma DE, X-server, nVidia card GTX 650 (GK107) + nVidia RPM's from Negativo17.

works for me:
desktop 16GB Intel i7-3770 CPU, using the Mate Desktop Environment
works, no regression noted.
Looks fine on x260
Works here on T450s and XS35GTv2.

Seems fine here on laptop with external monitor/keyboard/mouse: i3-7100T, 8GB RAM, Intel 630 GPU

First kernel regression test failed (cachedrop) but passed the second and third time I ran the test.
Tested on local machine (TravelMate B117).
works for me
Tested on virtual machine with AMD Ryzen 5 2400G.

Just upgraded from 5.05 and this version do not boot on RPi3B+ for me.

Screenshot: https://dwrobel.fedorapeople.org/tmp/screenshots/rpi3b+-kernel-5.06.jpg
5.0.6 has run normally. The default tests passed/skipped.
works for me
No regressions noted.
Tested on virtual machine with AMD Ryzen 5 2400G.
No regressions on T480s i5-8250U iGPU.
Tested on Lenovo T480s.  Does NOT bootup, waits on udev and LVM indefinitely. Forced reboot did not completed.
No regressions spotted on IvyBridge / Radeon HD 7670m hybrid and Broadwell laptop.

bugs.title: CVE-2019-3882 kernel: denial of service vector through vfio DMA mappings

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2019-3882 kernel: denial of service vector through vfio DMA mappings

long_desc.thetext:
A flaw was found in the Linux kernel vfio interface implementation that permits violation of the user's locked memory limit. If a device is bound to a vfio driver, such as vfio-pci, and the local attacker is administratively granted ownership of the device, it may cause a system memory exhaustion and thus a denial of service (DoS).

References:

https://seclists.org/oss-sec/2019/q2/6

A suggested fix:

https://lore.kernel.org/lkml/155414977872.12780.13728555131525362206.stgit@gimli.home/T/#u

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 1695571]

kernel-5.0.6-100.fc28, kernel-headers-5.0.6-100.fc28, kernel-tools-5.0.6-100.fc28 has been pushed to the Fedora 28 stable repository. If problems still persist, please make note of it in this bug report.

kernel-5.0.6-200.fc29, kernel-headers-5.0.6-200.fc29, kernel-tools-5.0.6-200.fc29 has been pushed to the Fedora 29 stable repository. If problems still persist, please make note of it in this bug report.

Acknowledgments:

Name: Alex Williamson (Red Hat Inc.)

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7

Via RHSA-2019:2029 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2019:2029

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7

Via RHSA-2019:2043 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2019:2043

This bug is now closed. Further updates for individual products will be reflected on the CVE page(s):

https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/cve-2019-3882

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8

Via RHSA-2019:3309 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2019:3309

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8

Via RHSA-2019:3517 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2019:3517

bugs.title: [kernel 5.0.x] IO Schedulers shoud be included in the kernel

bugzilla.short_desc: [kernel 5.0.x] IO Schedulers shoud be included in the kernel

long_desc.thetext:
CONFIG_MQ_IOSCHED_KYBER=m
CONFIG_IOSCHED_BFQ=m

should be:

CONFIG_MQ_IOSCHED_KYBER=y
CONFIG_IOSCHED_BFQ=y



Config from 4.xx was:
CONFIG_IOSCHED_NOOP=y
CONFIG_IOSCHED_DEADLINE=y
CONFIG_IOSCHED_CFQ=y



Thank you.
Can you elaborate on why we need these builtin? I'm not opposed I just want to make sure this is documented.

Default i/o sched is changed at "boot time" from kernel command line in grub:
https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_enterprise_linux/7/html-single/performance_tuning_guide/#sect-Red_Hat_Enterprise_Linux-Performance_Tuning_Guide-Configuration_tools-Setting_the_default_IO_scheduler
Thanks for the pointer. Based on other feedback as well, I think this makes sense. I'll push this for all 5.x branches and it should be picked up with the 5.0.6 build.

bugs.title: CVE-2019-9857 kernel: memory leak in inotify_update_existing_watch() leads to denial of service

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2019-9857 kernel: memory leak in inotify_update_existing_watch() leads to denial of service

long_desc.thetext:
In the Linux kernel through 5.0.2, the function inotify_update_existing_watch() in fs/notify/inotify/inotify_user.c neglects to call fsnotify_put_mark() with IN_MASK_CREATE after fsnotify_find_mark(), which will cause a memory leak (aka refcount leak). Finally, this will cause a denial of service.

Upstream patch: 
https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/jack/linux-fs.git/commit/?h=fsnotify&id=62c9d2674b31d4c8a674bee86b7edc6da2803aea

References:  
https://patchwork.kernel.org/patch/10836283/

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 1694759]

kernel-5.0.6-100.fc28, kernel-headers-5.0.6-100.fc28, kernel-tools-5.0.6-100.fc28 has been pushed to the Fedora 28 stable repository. If problems still persist, please make note of it in this bug report.

kernel-5.0.6-200.fc29, kernel-headers-5.0.6-200.fc29, kernel-tools-5.0.6-200.fc29 has been pushed to the Fedora 29 stable repository. If problems still persist, please make note of it in this bug report.
